moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4: Difficult opening, hard to play for white
moves.6... Bc5+ 7. Kh1 Qf6 8. c3 Nc6 9. d4 Nxd:
I am not sure about giving back the knight.
It seems to me that white has to large an advantage in development.

For me personally, I like games where I have a lead in development.
moves.10. cxd4 Bxd4 11. Nc3:
Blocking he diagonal to b2, and threateing Nd5 in the process.
Maybe black should just exchange some pieces here with Bxc3, to reduce white's development advantage.
moves.12. Bxf4 h5: Preventing the threatening Qh5, but black falls even further behind in development.
moves.13. e5: This one cannot be taken, black cannot afford to open the e1-e8 line.
moves.13... Qf5 14. Ne4:
Punishment for not trading the Bisshop for the Knight.
Of course Nd6 is threatening.
moves.14... Qg4:
I exepcted 14...,Bxe5; 15.Nd6+ !, Bxd6; 16.Bxd6, Qxf3, Rxf3;

Blacks King is then caught in a net, even with no Queens on the board.
In fact if wite plays correctly, the checkmate is forced.

Instead of 15.ND6+, the more simple Ra1-e1 is also good, but not as strong.
moves.15. Bg5:
Still attemting to trap blacks King.
This was probably black last chance to play d5 and escape the net.
moves.15... Qxf3 16. Nd6+:
Ha! 
Blacks bisshop and rook are trapped beind the wall of his own pawns.
White has to act with a little haste, but in a sense he has a rook and a bisshop extra on the board.
Blacks King remains in the net, even without the Queens.
moves.16... Kf8 17. Rxf3: Preparing an attack over the f-file, by doubling the rooks.
moves.18. Re1: Not bad, but exf6 would have been stronger, blocking e7 for black King.
moves.19... Ba6 20. f7:
Once again white has to play aggressively.

The only way to prevent White promoting a Queen is Nh6 or Nf6.
Both moves lose a lot of material however.

Finally Black realized there is no more escape, and he resigned.
